event.title: Feeding the Little Masses - Lecture
event.shortdesc: "Feeding the Little Masses: Envisioning School Food in the Obesity Era" by Melissa Salazar.

fulldesc.p: This lecture, which is free and open to the public, will showcase photographs of California school food and cafeterias as a way to spark debate about efforts to reform school feeding practices in the U.S. due to child obesity concerns. The photos make visible the issues faced by school districts and cafeteria workers in trying to meet USDA requirements while providing a pleasant and healthful eating experience for students and meeting their financial bottom line. Photos taken by schoolchildren reveal interesting differences between the lunchtime agendas of children and the adults who hope to encourage children's healthier eating at school.

Â

event.title: Praying With Lior
event.shortdesc: An engrossing, wrenching and tender documentary film, PRAYING WITH LIOR introduces Lior Liebling, also called "the little rebbe." Lior has Down syndrome, and has spent his entire life praying with utter abandon. Is he a "spiritual genius" as many around him say?
event.fulldesc: An engrossing, wrenching and tender documentary film, PRAYING WITH LIOR introduces Lior Liebling, also called "the little rebbe." Lior has Down syndrome, and has spent his entire life praying with utter abandon. Is he a "spiritual genius" as many around him say? Or simply the vessel that contains everyone's unfulfilled wishes and expectations? Lior - whose name means "my light" - lost his mother at age six, and her words and spirit hover over the film. While everyone agrees Lior is closer to God, he's also a burden, a best friend, an inspiration, and an embarrassment, depending on which family member is speaking. As Lior approaches Bar Mitzvah, the Jewish coming-of-age ceremony different characters provides a window into life spent "praying with Lior." The movie poses difficult questions such as what is "disability" and who really talks to God? Told with intimacy and humor, PRAYING WITH LIOR is a family story, a triumph story, a grief story, a divinely-inspired story.

fulldesc.p: THE COMPLETE HISTORY OF AMERICA (abridged)..Special Election Year Edition is the creation of theÂ Reduced Shakespeare CompanyÂ a three-man comedy troupe known for taking long, serious subjects and reducing them into short, sharp comedies. They have created six stage shows, two television specials, and numerous radio pieces. In addition to on going tours of the U.S. and Great Britain, they have performed at the White House, Lincoln Center, the Kennedy Center and London's West End.

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; min-height: 15px; margin: 0px
font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: THE COMPLETE HISTORY OF AMERICA (abridged)-Special Election Year Edition takesÂ 600

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: Years of History in 6000 seconds! From Washington to Watergate, yea verily from the Bering Straits to Baghdad, from New World to New World Order, the three cultural guerillas of the Reduced Shakespeare Company will take you on a ninety minute roller coaster ride through the glorious quagmire that is American History.

event.title: Fall Fling

fulldesc.p: Fall Fling offers a host of fun activities!

Craft and food vendors, entertainment, clowns, stilt walkers, petting zoo, pony rides, games and activities including the Forgotten Friends Reptile Interactive Show from 12 p.m. to 2 p.m., Pet Costume Contest 12:30 p.m., and the Marauder Treasure Hunt for kids age 510 years from 2:30 p.m. to 4 p.m.
Shop at local craft booths and relax in our lighted and heated tent.
Purchase a variety of foods including crabcakes, burgers, hot dogs, funnel cakes, pretzels, kettle corn, blooming onions, fries, and so much more.
Admission is free.
Game fees raise money for student and local organizations.

event.title: Italian American Reconciliation by John Patrick Shanley
event.shortdesc: Italian American Reconciliation presented by Millersville University Theatre

div.p: Italian American Reconciliation by John Patrick ShanleyÂ
A University Theatre Production

p.strong: November 7, 8, 13, 14, 15 at 8:00 PMÂ
November 9 & 16 at 2:00 PMÂ

div.p: Rafters Theatre, Dutcher Hall, Millersville UniversityÂ
Director Tony Elliot
TICKETS: Open Seating
$10.00 Public
$7.00 MU ID (at the door), Senior Citizens, and Students
$5.00 MU ID super saver advance sales only at the SMC
Tickets can be purchased Mon-Fri, 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM at the Student Memorial Center or by calling 717-872-3811 and online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com

John Patrick Shanley, the award winning author of Doubt and Moonstruck, brings us a fanciful, lighthearted and zestfully comic look at male/female relationships - and the sometimes dangerous (and very funny) complications that can result.

Huey is safely divorced from his shrewish first wife, Janice, who shot his dog and may have tried to shoot him. Huey feels he cannot regain his "manhood" until he woos and wins her one more time.Â Huey enlists the aid of his lifelong buddy, Aldo Scalicki, a confirmed bachelor and not-so-slick ladies-man, to win her back.Â The problem is, Janice has always hated Aldo, too.
Little Italy comes to Millersville with all of the passion of Grand Opera in a play you will not want to miss! Â

p.strong: AUDITIONS: September 15 & 16, 7:00 PM to 10:00 PM, Dutcher Hall

event.title: Lecture - Buruli Ulcer
event.shortdesc: Education Series - Buruli Ulcer: Mystery Disease

fulldesc.p: Buruli Ulcer: ecology, epidemiology and socio-economical aspects of a "mystery disease'" from West Africa toAustralia
Presented by Dr. John Wallace, associate professor of biology,Millersville University
Sponsored by the Office of Social Equity and Diversity
Free and open to the public.

contact.name: Dr. John Wallace, associate professor of biology

fulldesc.p: Project Green Lancaster: "Leaving Green Footprints"
Workshop with memoir writer Thomas Larson
Sponsored by Millersville University Dept. of English and the Lancaster Literary GuildÂ
Ticket is required: free for MU students, faculty and staff. Fee for public and Literary Guild members.

Dr. Curtis A. Pettaway, a Millersville alumnus of the class of 1978, will be the keynote speaker for the December 2008 commencement.Â Pettaway is a professor of urology and cancer biology at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, and medical director of the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center Prostate Outreach Project, a federally funded project to promote prostate cancer detection in underserved communities.Â His areas of interest also include clinical and basic research in tumor and host factors associated with prostate cancer progression.
Commencement is scheduled for Sunday, December 14 at 2 p.m. in Pucillo Gymnasium on the Millersville campus.Â More information is available at:Â http://www.millersville.edu/commencement/.

Pettaway graduated with honors from Temple University School of Medicine in 1983, and in 1983 he was the recipient of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation Merit Scholar, the I.A. Burnett Award in the Department of Surgery, and the Department of Urology Award.Â He has also received numerous awards for his work in cancer treatment.Â In 1997, he received the Faculty Excellence Award from the University of Texas M.D. Cancer Center.
Â

event.title: Winter Conference "How to make a difference: Civic engagement at MU"
event.shortdesc: Winter Conference "How to make a difference: Civic engagement at MU"
event.fulldesc:
Winter Conference "How to make a difference: Civic engagement at MU"
January 25, 2008 from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
Bolger Conference Center
How To Make A Difference:
Conference Topics:
- Civic Engagement: What Does It Mean and Why Is It Important?
- Community-based Research and Service-learning: Getting Involved Is Easier than You Think
- The Role of Civic Engagement in the Professional Growth of Faculty
- How Civic Engagement Can Benefit Students' Personal & Career Growth
Conference Schedule:
8:00 - 8:30 Breakfast & Welcome
8:30 - 9:30 Keynote Dr. Robert Bringle, Chancellor's Professor of Psychology and Philanthropic Studies; Director, Center for Service and Learning, IUPUI
9:45 - 12:00 Session I
12:15 - 1:15 Lunch
1:30 - 3:45 Session II
4:00 - 4:30 Closing Session
Conference Registration: Please register for the conference at http://www.surveymonkey.com/s.aspx?sm=VYWdnfdYj6qMZli1XHKsbA_3d_3d
Sponsored by Millersville University's Civic and Community Engagement
and Research Project (CCERP) & Campus Compact

event.title: Sonic Cinema: Relache Ensemble with Maya Deren Films
event.shortdesc: Relache Ensemble with Maya Deren Films
event.fulldesc:
On January 25th at 7 p.m., internationally renowned, Philly-based chamber ensemble Relache will perform alongside Maya Deren films in Lyte Auditorium. Admission is free and open to the public.
RELA‚CHE, for a quarter century, has maintained an international reputation as a leader in commissioning, presenting and performing the innovative and exciting music of our time. Relache is among the oldest continuously operating, nonprofit organizations and chamber ensembles dedicated to contemporary music in the United States. It has consistently offered world-class performances and presentations of music by leading American and international composers and artists. In addition, Relache has always invested heavily in the future of new music through its commitment to the work of young and emerging composers. To date, Relache has performed more than 550 concerts in the Greater Philadelphia area, around the country and the globe, including residency, festival and touring appearances in South America, Japan and Eastern and Western Europe. The Ensemble boasts a touring-ready repertoire of over 50 pieces and a repertory library of over 400 works. Nearly 140 of these are Relache commissions, including works by Robert Ashley, Kitty Brazelton, John Cage, Uri Caine, Fred Frith, Kyle Gann, Philip Glass, Fred Ho, Michael Nyman, Pauline Oliveros, Bobby Previte, George Russell, Somei Satoh, and Lois V Vierk, just to name a few. Relache has released three CD's to date: Relache on Edge (1991, Mode), Outcome Inevitable (1994, O.O. Disks) and Pick it up (1997, Monroe Street), which was nominated for a Grammy in 1998.
The Maya Deren films will include At Land, Meshes of the Afternoon, and The Very Eye of Night.
Some humorous interludes will include Dream of a Rarebit Fiend (1906) and Beggar on Horseback (1925)
For more information on the group, see http://www.relache.org/
For more information on the event, contact Jill Craven (jill.craven@millersville.edu).
The visit is sponsored by the Women's Film and Lecture Series and The MU Cine Club.

fulldesc.p: Music from Millersville is an off-campus concert series which connects with and brings our music to the larger community. Concerts take place at St. James Episcopal in Lancaster.

Juilliard Trained Dr. Maria Corley explores works by master composers written at the end of their careers. Guest artists include cellist and retired faculty member Peter Brye and Dr. Christy Banks, clarinet.

event.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration Lecture
event.shortdesc: Currently serving as a senior lecturer at Yale University in the African American studies department Kathleen Neal Cleaver has spent most of her life participating in the human rights struggle.

fulldesc.p: Currently serving as a senior lecturer at Yale University in the African American studies department Kathleen Neal Cleaver has spent most of her life participating in the human rights struggle. In the late 1960's Cleaver served as the Communications secretary and the first female member of the central committee for the Black Panther Party. Cleaver is the recipient of many awards and fellowships and has also written for numerous magazines and newspapers.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Millersville University: Carnival Day
event.shortdesc: Millersville University will host Carnival Day 2008 from 1- 4 p.m. Feb. 2 at Pucillo Gymnasium.
event.fulldesc:
The women's and men's basketball team will play a doubleheader against East Stroudsburg University. The women tipoff at 1 p.m. and men's action begins at 3 p.m.
The first 50 children 12 years of age or younger will receive a free Carnival Day T-shirt. Kids also receive free admission with the purchase of an adult ticket. Lancaster Barnstormers' mascot Cylo, and NCAA mascot JJ Jumper will be in attendance.
Adult tickets cost $6, senior citizens are $3, visiting students are free, MU students with ID are free and parking is free. Concession stand will be open.
For more information, contact Gretchen Imes at 872-3361.

event.title: Admissions Open House
event.shortdesc: Millersville University is hosting a campus Open House on Saturday February 2, 2008.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University is hosting a campus Open House on Saturday February 2, 2008.

Admissions information, student life, programs of study and financial aid will be among the topics covered. Campus tours and faculty conferences will also be included in the program. Lunch will be available on campus and may be purchased for a nominal fee.

The program will begin at 8:30 a.m. on the Millersville campus. For more information and to register, visit the MU web site at www.millersville.edu or contact the Admissions Office at 1-800-MU-ADMIT or (717) 872-3371.

event.title: The Vagina Monologues
event.shortdesc: The Vagina Monologues at Millersville University. All the proceeds benefit the Milagro House.

fulldesc.p: Benefit performances of "The Vagina Monologues" have been done in thousands of colleges and universities since 1998, with unrivaled success. These events have been responsible for raising millions of dollars for local charities over the last 10 years.The purpose of these events is to raise awareness about violence against women and girls as well as raise money for local beneficiaries that are working to end the violence.
Â At Millersville University all the proceeds benefit the Milagro House, a transitional facility in Lancaster for women and children and the Domestic Violence Services of Lancaster.

TICKET PRICES: General Admission: $10.00 MU ID (1 per ID): $5.00 Tickets are available for purchase online at www.muticketsonline.com or by calling the Student Memorial Center Box Office at (717) 872-3811 Monday thru Friday 8:00 a.m. - 4 p.m. Sponsored by the Women's Commission at Millersville University www.vday.org.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Children of Men
event.shortdesc: The Humanities Film Series/MU Cine Club will present a free screening of Alfonso Cuaron's 2006 film Children of Men in Myers Auditorium in McComsey Building.

fulldesc.p: The Humanities Film Series/MU CinÃ© Club will present a free screening of Alfonso CuarÃ´n's 2006 film Children of Men in Myers Auditorium in McComsey Building.

This thriller was nominated for Oscars for its achievements in cinematography, editing, and writing. The film will be introduced by Dr. Chuck Ward of the Philosophy Department, who will also lead discussion after the film.
The screening is FREE and OPEN TO THE PUBLIC. For more information on the film, see http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0206634/
For more information on the Humanities Film Series, contact Dr. Jill Craven or Dr. Jen Miller.

event.title: Music from Millersville
event.shortdesc: Music from Millersville is a concert series that connects with and brings our music to the larger community.

fulldesc.p: Music from Millersville is a concert series that connects with and brings our music to the larger community. Concerts take place at St. James Episcopal Church in Lancaster.

The best musicians from Millersville's Junior class compete for the Vyner Award. The winner, chosen as a result of his or her performance in this concert, will receive a stipend and will become Millersville senior soloist for the 2008-09 school year.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.location: St. James Episcopal Church, Lancaster, PA

event.title: Little Shop of Horrors 2/22-3/2
event.shortdesc: University Theatre presents: Little Shop of Horrors - Runs 2/22 - 3/2

fulldesc.p:
PERFORMANCES:
February 22,23,24, 8:00 PM
February 26,27,28, 7:30 PM
February 29, 8:00 PM
March 1, 2:00 PM and 8:00 PM
March 2, 2:00 PM

Seymour, a down-and-out skid row floral assistant becomes an overnight sensation when he discovers an exotic plant with a mysterious craving for blood. Soon the plant, "Audrey IIâ, grows into an ill-tempered, foul-mouthed, Rhythm & Blues singing carnivore with an ever-growing need to be fed. One of the longest running off-Broadway shows of all time, this hilarious spoof of the 1950's sci-fi movies is an outrageously entertaining show that never fails to catch the audience off guard.
If you don't know the show, don't miss it. If you do know the show, you will want to see it at the Rafters Theatre. We are adding performances for this one, so get your tickets early.

Dutcher Hall
TBA
Contact Gene Ellis @ 717-872-3888 or eugene.ellis@millersville.edu

event.title: Little Shop of Horrors
event.shortdesc: University Theatre presents: Little Shop of Horrors

fulldesc.p:
PERFORMANCES:
February 22,23,24, 8:00 PM
February 26,27,28, 7:30 PM
February 29, 8:00 PM
March 1, 2:00 PM and 8:00 PM
March 2, 2:00 PM

Seymour, a down-and-out skid row floral assistant becomes an overnight sensation when he discovers an exotic plant with a mysterious craving for blood. Soon the plant, "Audrey IIâ, grows into an ill-tempered, foul-mouthed, Rhythm & Blues singing carnivore with an ever-growing need to be fed. One of the longest running off-Broadway shows of all time, this hilarious spoof of the 1950's sci-fi movies is an outrageously entertaining show that never fails to catch the audience off guard.
If you don't know the show, don't miss it. If you do know the show, you will want to see it at the Rafters Theatre. We are adding performances for this one, so get your tickets early.

event.title: Ailey II
event.shortdesc: Ailey II is an exceptional company that merges the spirit and energy of the country''s best young dance talent with the passion and creative vision of today''s most outstanding merging choreographers.

fulldesc.p: Ailey II is an exceptional company that merges the spirit and energy of the country''s best young dance talent with the passion and creative vision of today''s most outstanding merging choreographers.

Ailey II began in 1974 as the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble, when Alvin Ailey initiated a workshop composed of the most promising scholarship students from The Ailey School. The original members of Ailey II were handpicked by Mr. Ailey from among that group. The Company, which emphasizes a balance of repertoire, technique and performance, has become one of the most popular dance companies in the United States.

Under the direction of Sylvia Waters, Ailey II invigorates the American dance scene by offering unique opportunities for artists. Ailey II members, who have each completed advanced programs at The Ailey School, refine their technique while gaining invaluable performing and teaching experience during their tenure with the Company (usually two years).

Throughout its history, more than 50 Ailey II members have been selected to join Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Many others have gone on to pursue successful careers as dancers, teachers and choreographers with other professional dance companies, on Broadway and in schools.
Sponsored by the Cultural Affairs Committee
Tickets available February 4, 2008
Monday Friday 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM, by calling 717-872-3811 or at muticketsonline.com

$5.00 w/ MU ID, Seniors Citizens, K-12
$15.00 General Admission

event.title: Latino Celebration Cultural Education Series
event.shortdesc: "To be Seen, Heard and Remembered: A Call to Action for Latinos and Friends" by Dr. Kimberly Mahaffy, Associate Professor of Sociology, and Dr. Shawn Gallagher, Assistant Professor of Psychology, Millersville University

fulldesc.h3: Dr. Kimberly Mahaffy and Dr. Shawn Gallagher

p.strong: "To be Seen, Heard and Remembered: A Call to Action for Latinos and Friends"

fulldesc.p: A participatory experimental workshop that will shape Millersville's collective memory to include Latinos and Latinas. Join us to reflect on the past and present contributions of Latinos at Millersville University.
Sponsored by the Latino Studies Minor, Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration Committee, and the Office of Social Equity and Diversity.
This event is free and open to the public.
Lunch is provided at 11:30 a.m. Pre-register by calling 717-872-3787 or 3788. Presentations begin at noon.

event.location: Old Main Dining Room, Gordinier Hall

event.title: Conrad Nelson Lecture
event.shortdesc: Heimo Wallner, Austrian Printmaker and Animator Wallner Exhibition: March 17-April 17, 2008

fulldesc.h4: Heimo Wallner, Austrian Printmaker and Animator
fulldesc.p: Heimo Wallner, was born in Salzburg, Austria in 1961. He studied sculpture at the Vienna Academy of Art and has shown work in Croatia, Italy, Mexico, Japan, and throughout the United States. Recently, Wallner exhibited work in the International Print Center of New York''s New Prints Program.
Wallner is widely recognized for his ambitious, experimental work that defies categorization as it spans drawing, installation, sculpture, animation and printmaking.

Wallner''s drawings manipulate body parts, actions, and expressions to create what he refers to as "a vocabulary of emotions." The images serve as symbols for words representing a compendium of life''s experiences. In effect it is drawing as an extension of thought. In his own words he describes the process "I draw from segment to segment- jumping here to there until the surface closes and images turn into textures, structures, ornaments-"
This lecture is free and open to the public.

event.title: Charles Burnett's "Killer of Sheep"
event.shortdesc: Screening of Charles Burnett's Killer of Sheep

fulldesc.p: Screening will be in Myers Auditorium in McComsey Building (Millersville Campus) and is free to the public. Discussion will follow.
See http://www.killerofsheep.com/buy.html for more information.

"Killer of Sheep represents the highest example of contemporary black American life put on screen because of Burnett's integrity to view it purely, without typical corrupted Hollywood devices." ARMOND WHITE, FILM COMMENT

Writer/Director Charles Burnett submitted his first feature, Killer of Sheep, as his thesis for his MFA in film at UCLA. The film was shot on location near his family's home in Watts in a series of weekends on a shoestring budget of less than $10,000, most of which was grant money.

With a mostly amateur cast (consisting of Burnett's friends and acquaintances), much handheld camera work, episodic narrative and gritty documentary-style cinematography, Killer of Sheep has been compared by film critics and scholars to Italian neorealist films like Vittorio De Sica's The Bicycle Thief and Roberto Rossellini's Paisan. However, Burnett cites Basil Wright's Songs of Ceylon and Night Mail and Jean Renoir's The Southerner as his main influences.

In 1981, Killer of Sheep received the Critic's Award at the Berlin International Film Festival. In 1990, the Library of Congress declared it a national treasure and placed it among the first 50 films entered in the National Film Registry for its historical significance. In 2002, the National Society of Film Critics selected the film as one of the 100 Essential Films of all time.

Despite these accolades, the film never saw popular distribution due to the expense and complication of the music rights (including songs by Etta James, Dinah Washington, Gershwin, Rachmaninov, Paul Robeson and Earth, Wind & Fire on the soundtrack) and in its rare viewings at festivals and museums it was shown on ragged 16mm prints. Now, thirty years later, the new 35mm print, restored by UCLA Film & Television Archive, is ready for its long-awaited theatrical release.
This film is brought to MU by African American Studies, The MU CinÃ© Club, and the Women's Film and Lecture Series.

WINNER OF 'APPRENTICE' TO SPEAK AT MILLERSVILLE
Â
Â Dr. Randal D. Pinkett, winner of the 4th season of NBC's "The Apprenticeâ will be coming to Millersville University of Pennsylvania on Tuesday, March 25th to give a presentation to students. Pinkett is the founder, chairman and CEO of Building Community Technology (BCT) Partners, a multimillion dollar management, technology and policy consulting services firm.
Â Pinkett has a total of five degrees, including a bachelor's degree from Rutgers University, a master's from the University of Oxford in England and a master's, MBA, and Ph.D. from Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Â Recognized by "USA Todayâas one of the "Top 20 Scholars in the country,â Pinkett has also received numerous awards including the NCAA Academic All-American. Currently the author of two books, titled "Campus CEO: The Student Entrepreneur's Guide to Launching a Multimillion-Dollar Businessâand "No-Money Down CEO: How to Start Your Dream Business with Little or No Cash,â Pinkett is a highly valued speaker for various colleges, universities and corporations.
Â Sponsored by the Black Student Union at Millersville, Pinkett's presentation, "Think Like An Entrepreneurâ will begin at 7:30 p.m. in Lehr Dining Hall. This event is free and open to the public. For more information, contact Jonathan Sanders at jonathan6603@hotmail.com.

event.shortdesc: Breaking barriers and setting records in the military, Lieutenant Colonel (Retired) Consuelo Castillo Kickbush rose to senior officer position and became the highest-ranking Hispanic woman in the Combat Support Field of the United States Army.

Acknowledged as a charismatic, passionate and entertaining speaker, Consuelo Kickbusch, carries her powerful message of what it takes to be an effective leader in today''s global marketplace to hundreds of colleges/universities, corporations and government institutions, both here in the U.S. and abroad.

event.title: 28th Annual Conference on the Holocaust
event.shortdesc: "Atrocities Outlawed, Human Rights Affirmed: The International Quest to Halt Genocide Since 1948"

fulldesc.p: U.S. Foreign Policy in an Age of Terror:Â Can Genocide Be Stopped? by Dr. Samantha Power

Dr. Power is the Anna Lindh Professor of Practice of Global Leadership and Public Policy at the Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University. She is the award-winning author of "A Problem from Hellâ: America and the Age of GenocideÂ which won the 2003 Pulitzer Prize for general nonfiction, the 2003 National Book Critics Circle Award and the Council on Foreign Relations' Arthur Ross Prize for best book on U.S. foreign policy. Power's New Yorker article on the horrors in Darfur, Sudan, won the 2005 National Magazine Award.
28th Annual Conference on the Holocaust and Genocide "Atrocities Outlawed, Human Rights Affirmed: The International Quest to Halt Genocide since 1948"
The conference is free and open to the public.

event.title: 28th Annual Conference on the Holocaust
event.shortdesc: "Atrocities Outlawed, Human Rights Affirmed: The International Quest to Halt Genocide Since 1948"
event.fulldesc:
28th Annual Conference on the Holocaust and Genocide "Atrocities Outlawed, Human Rights Affirmed: The International Quest to Halt Genocide since 1948" Bolger Conference Center
9:00 a.m. Good Germans and the Holocaust:Â Lessons for Today Â (Lehr Room) - Robert P. Ericksen, Pacific Lutheran University
10:30 a.m. - Panel Discussions (Lehr Room). The Politics of War Crimes Trials in Historical PerspectiveÂ Â Â Â A round table presented by scholars of the the Center for Advanced Holocaust Studies at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum featuring an international panel with Suzanne Brown-Fleming, Martin Dean, Donald Bloxham and Devin O. Pendas.
2:00 p.m. - The Language of Genocide: Criminal Justice, History and Government. An international panel of experts addresses contemporary and historical issues with Steven Jacobs, University of Alabama; Paul R. Bartrop, Bialik College, Australia; Alex Alvarez, Northern Arizona University; Herbert Hirsch, Virginia Commonwealth University. ***Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â
4 p.m.Â - Military and Diplomatic Intervention (University Room) Presentations on NATO, U. S. military operations and the Criminal Tribunal in the Hague by Ralph E. Brown III ofÂ California State University, Douglas Peifer of the Air War College and Peter Russell of the University of Melbourne.
4 p.m.Â - The Holocaust as Personal Journey (Matisse Room) Author Ellen Cassedy, Simonetta Milli Konewko of the University of Wisconsin and Saulius SuÅ¾iedÄlis of Millersville University discuss Holocaust memories as experienced in Lithuania and Poland.
7Â p.m.Â - An Evening with the Victims of Darfur: What I Saw in Darfur: Thoughts on the Devil. Megan Bremer of the Pennsylvania Immigration Resources Center recounts her recent experiences in Darfur. FILM: "The Devil Came on Horseback." Winner of the Seeds of War Documentary Film Festival and Official Selection of the 2007 Sundance Film Festival. This documentary recounts the travails of Brian Steidle, a former Marine who served as a monitor with the African Union in Sudan.

event.title: The Legacy of Matthew Shepard
event.shortdesc: Through her national speaking program, Judy Shepard shares Matthew's values of respect and dignity for others.

fulldesc.p: Through her national speaking program, Judy Shepard shares Matthew's values of respect and dignity for others. She is determined to make a difference - to do what she can to ensure that no other parent will have to endure what she has. Judy speaks to audiences nationwide about what they can do to make their schools and communities more accepting of everyone, regardless of sex, national origin, race, religion, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity and/or expression. This program has been presented to over one million people at colleges, high schools, universities, churches, businesses and symposiums worldwide.
The talk will be held in the Student Memorial Center - Multipurpose Room. It is free and open to the public.

event.title: 28th Annual Conference on the Holocaust
event.shortdesc: "Atrocities Outlawed, Human Rights Affirmed: The International Quest to Halt Genocide Since 1948"

fulldesc.p: 9 a.m. - Justice for Genocide and Crimes againstÂ Humanity: Progress and DeterrenceÂ (Lehr Room)Â - Louis Aucoin, Tufts University.

10:45 a. m. - Genocide: Politics, Justice and EducationÂ (University Room). Educational and political issues concerning genocide prevention discussed by Gary A. Kulhanjian of Kean University, Mary Johnson of Florida Atlantic University and Scott Racek of the University of Maryland.
10:45 a. m. - Medicine and Genocide (Matisse Room). Steven Friedman of Gratz College and Andrea Szkil of Richard Stockton College present issues of forensic policy and genocide.Â Â

2:00 p.m. What I Saw at Nuremberg: The Relevance of the Trials in Today's WorldÂ (University Room) - Henry T. King, Case Western Reserve University One of only three still active prosecutors who served with the International Military Tribunal of Nuremberg (1945-1946) evaluates the contemporary relevance of the trials (Media Presentation).

event.title: African American Music Forum: Composers and Performers
event.shortdesc: African American Music Forum: Darryl Taylor and Dr. Maria Corley

fulldesc.p: Darryl Taylor, counter tenor and Dr. Maria Corley, piano, along with additional Millersville University faculty and students perform selections composed by H. Leslie Adams.

Darryl Taylor is a co-director of voice studies on the music faculty of the University of California, Irvine. As a countertenor, Mr. Taylor has performed in concert halls across the United States and Europe, including Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall. In 2006, he released two CDs, Love Rejoices: Songs of H. Leslie Adams, and Fields of Wonder: Songs of Robert Owens. He is the founder of the African American Song Alliance and has lectured at the Juilliard School, the Manhattan School of Music, and the University of Michigan.
Sponsored by the University Theme Program, Frederick Douglass Celebration of Black Culture, Cultural Affairs Committee, and Commission on Cultural Diversity.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: African American Music Forum: Darryl Taylor

fulldesc.p: Darryl Taylor is a co-director of voice studies on the music faculty of the University of California, Irvine. As a countertenor, Mr. Taylor has performed in concert halls across the United States and Europe, including Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall. In 2006, he released two CDs, Love Rejoices: Songs of H. Leslie Adams, and Fields of Wonder: Songs of Robert Owens. He is the founder of the African American Song Alliance and has lectured at the Juilliard School, the Manhattan School of Music, and the University of Michigan.
Taylor performs with Juilliard-trained Dr. Maria Corley, a member of the Millersville University faculty.
Sponsored by the University Theme Program, Frederick Douglass Celebration of Black Culture, Cultural Affairs Committee, and Commission on Cultural Diversity.

event.title: African American Music Forum: Composers and Performers
event.shortdesc: African American Music Forum: Richard Thompson

fulldesc.p: This evening, Richard Thompson performs with Millersville University faculty and students. The ensemble performance will include the works of H. Leslie Adams and Richard Thompson.
Â

Richard Thompson is a performer and composer whose work resists a single stylistic category. His compositions combine European and African-American styles, so that the formal structures of European classical music develop ideas, which are essentially jazz in nature. Originally from Aberdeen, Scotland, Mr. Thompson made his debut at the Purcell Room, in the Royal Festival Hall in London. He has appeared in live broadcasts for B.B.C. Jazz and Classical Radio, Italian National Television and Radio and also given concerts at La Piccola Scala in Milan, among many others. His orchestral appearances include The Harlem Festival Orchestra, The Boston Orchestra and Chorale, The Glasgow Chamber Orchestra and The Aberdeen Chamber Orchestra.
In 1999 Thompson was awarded the first Individual Artist Award for classical music composition from The Brooklyn Arts Council. The winning piece, Legend Of The Moors, is a musical depiction of the presence and influence of the Moors in Spain during the Middle Ages. The piece was premiered at The Brooklyn Conservatory in 1999. In 2000 he premiered an orchestral piece entitled Voices with the Long Island Sound Symphony Orchestra under Dorothy Savitch. A discussion of some of his compositions appears in the 1998 textbook entitled, "African-American Music, An Introduction" by Dr. Earl Stewart, published by Simon and Schuster Macmillan/Prentice Hall International.
Sponsored by the University Theme Program, Frederick Douglass Celebration of Black Culture, Cultural Affairs Committee, and Commission on Cultural Diversity.
Â
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: University Theatre: Criminal Hearts
event.shortdesc: University Theatre presents: CRIMINAL HEARTS by Jane Martin PERFORMANCES: April 11-13, 17-19 at 8 p.m. April 20 at 2 p.m.

fulldesc.p: Sometimes you can meet your new best friend in the most unlikely place - like at home! Ata's unfaithful husband has left her, taking almost everything she owns. She's living on a diet of pizza and Dr. Pepper, sharpening pencils by the dozen to calm her nerves. Ata is also afraid to go outside.But when Bo breaks into her Chicago apartment to rob her one night, the society lady and the cat burglar unexpectedly find common ground.Friendship like this hasn't been seen since Thelma and Louise.

event.title: "Culture of Violence" by City of Asylum exiled writer-in-residence Horacio Castellanos Moya
event.shortdesc: City of Asylum/Pittsburgh provides sanctuary to writers exiled due to the threat of persecution.

fulldesc.p: City of Asylum/Pittsburgh provides sanctuary to writers exiled due to the threat of persecution. Mr. Horacio Castellanos Moya is among the leading contemporary Salvadoran novelists and short story writers. He was born in 1957 in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, though his family moved to El Salvador while he was only a few years old. He lived in San Salvador until 1979, and since has resided in Toronto, Canada, San Jose, Costa Rica, and Mexico City, working as a journalist and for the publisher EDUCA in Costa Rica. His first novel, La DiÃ¡spora, which concerns the struggles of the exiles from the Salvadoran Civil War, won the Premio Nacional de la Novela, awarded by the Universidad Centroamericana JosÃ© SimeÃ³n CaÃ±as, in 1988.

event.title: Lecture: The Culture of Violence in Latin America
event.shortdesc: Lecture by City of Asylum/Pittsburgh Exiled Writer-In-Residence: Horacio Castellanos Moya

fulldesc.p: The Culture of Violence in Latin America A Public Lecture by City of Asylum/Pittsburgh Exiled Writer-In-Residence: Horacio Castellanos Moya Exiled from El Salvador, Mr. Castellanos Moya has been praised as the voice of Central America.
FREE and open to the public.
Sponsored by the School of Humanities and Social Sciences, the departments of Foreign Languages, English, Sociology and Anthropology, LatinoStudies, and the Women?s Studies Program.

event.title: Hazeltine Women in Mathematics and Science Conference
event.shortdesc: The 21st Annual Glenna Hazeltine Women in Mathematics and Science Conference on Tuesday, April 15, 2008.
event.fulldesc:
21ST ANNUAL MATH AND SCIENCE CONFERENCE CELBRATES "SISTERS IN SCIENCEâ
Millersville University of Pennsylvania is hosting the 21st Annual Glenna Hazeltine Women in Mathematics and Science Conference on Tuesday, April 15, 2008.Â This year's conference will feature keynote speaker, Dr. Diann Jordan, from Alabama State University.Â Her lecture will be held in the Reighard Multi-Purpose Room in the Student Memorial Center (SMC) from 9 a.m. -10 a.m.
Each year the conference provides a forum for the exchange of information on careers in mathematics and the sciences.Â Jordan, a research scientist and professor, will give a presentation entitled "Sisters in Science: Celebrating All Women and Girls in Science."Â In addition, the role model presentations will feature women professionals from the science and mathematical fields who will share their educational background, professional duties and the professional benefits they enjoy.
Jordan was educated at Tuskegee University, Alabama A&M University and Michigan State University and has a Ph.D. in environmental soil microbiology.Â Before returning to Alabama, she worked for over 10 years as a professor at the University of Missouri-Columbia where she was the first woman faculty ever hired in the soil and atmospheric sciences dept., the first African American woman tenured in a research science department at the University of Missouri-Columbia (1996) and likely the first African American woman to earn a doctorate in soil science (microbiology) at Michigan State University in 1987.
Jordan has worked many years to educate others on the issues facing young women and minorities in science and math through seminars and lectures.Â She recently took her message beyond the walls of academia to a national audience and appeared on C-Span's Book TV and the Minnesota Public Radio.Â The lecture is free and open to the public.Â The event is sponsored by McNeil-PPC, Inc. and the Glenna Hazeltine Endowment.Â For more information, visit http://www.millersville.edu/~wmsc or contact Dr. Ximena P. CatepillÃ¡n, conference chair at (717) 872-3993.
event.location: Reighard Multi-Purpose Room in the Student Memorial Center

event.title: Performance: Alumni Band and Millersville Students
event.shortdesc: Concert: Millersville University alumni band will perform with the student concert band and wind ensemble. Robert Jager, guest conductor and composer.

fulldesc.p: For the first time in 10 years, the Millersville University alumni band will perform with the student concert band and wind ensemble. The event entitled a "Concert in Honor of our Music Alumni" will also feature nationally recognized guest conductor and composer Robert Jager. Jager will be working with both the concert band and wind ensemble. He will also lecture to Millersville University students and will work with high school bands in the area. Jager is a widely commissioned and performed composer with some 115 published works to his credit, including compositions for band, chorus, orchestra and various chamber ensembles.

The alumni band of Millersville University has been serving the greater Lancaster area with summer concerts focused on a patriotic theme. Among the finest musicians and music educators in the region, the music department alumni are an accomplished and widely recognized group of contributors to Pennsylvania's cultural welfare. Some of the musical performance pieces include "Sautereau" from Consort for Fifteen Wind Instruments by Robert Spittal, "Lollapalooza" by John Adams, and "Meditation on an Old Scottish Hymn Tune" and "First Suite for Band" by Robert Jager.
The concert is free and open to the public.

event.title: Jazz N Java
event.shortdesc: Jazz N Java on Saturday, May 3 at 7:30 p.m.

fulldesc.p: Back by popular demand, Jazz N Java will be held on Saturday, May 3, at 7:30 p.m. in the Student Memorial Center. Under the direction of Dr. Keith Wiley, join the Alumni Jazz Band and the Student Jazz Ensemble for an evening that will leave you in awe of Millersville's talented students and alumni. Dr. Wiley is the director of Jazz Bands, Concert Band conductor, and trumpet instructor at Millersville University, where he has been a member of the music faculty since 1984. He also teaches courses in instrumental music and general education. Dr. Wiley has performed with a variety of regional ensembles, including symphony, opera, chamber, and pit orchestras, as well as concert and jazz bands. In addition, he performs with a local jazz quintet, "Docsology," leads the Jazz Ministers Big Band, and is the musical director for the Hershey Area Playhouse. He and his students wow audiences annually at Jazz N Java.

Join the Alumni Association for an evening of music and dessert fanfare. This special concert offers a jazz club atmosphere. Tickets are $5.00 per person and includes event ticket, desserts and gourmet coffee.
Register for this event online at www.villealumni.com, or by calling the Alumni Services Office at 800-681-1855.

event.title: University meeting on Sirens
event.shortdesc: Millersville University will hold a public meeting on the new sirens on campus May 29.

fulldesc.p: Since the Virginia Tech tragedy, Millersville University has increased its emphasis on campus security.Â Blue security phones have been added around campus, the MU alert (text message) system is up and running and later this month the campus will be installing sirens as one more way to alert the community to potential threats.Â The sirens will be tested during the month of June.Â

The University is inviting the campus community as well a area residents to a public, informational meeting on the sirens.Â It will be held Thursday, May 29 at 7 p.m. in the Multipurpose room of the Student Memorial Center.
Summer 2

event.title: Homeland Security Symposium
event.shortdesc: Millersville University will host a Homeland Security Symposium on June 18.

p.strong: Â

fulldesc.p: Â

Chiefs of police, security directors, public safety directors, environmental health & safety directors and interested university personnel from across the region, will be at Millersville University on June 18 for a Homeland Security Symposium.Â Sponsored by The Protection Bureau, Panasonic Security & Digital Imaging Corporation and Cooper - Wheelock Industries, the conference will be held in the Multipurpose Room of the Student Memorial Center from 9 a.m. 3 p.m.
Â
"The symposium is an opportunity for experts in their field to explain the latest security trends and technologies,â explained University police chief, Wayne Silcox.Â
Â
Speakers will include:
Jim Powers, Pennsylvania Director of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security discussing "Unraveling the Complexities of Homeland Security,â and
Dan Currie from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security discussing the National Emergency Number Association.
Â
For more information or to RSVP, contact Debbie Jakeman, Director of Business Development,, 610-903-4986, by Monday, May 26th, 2008.

event.title: Patriotic Concert
event.fulldesc:
The Millersville University Summer Band will perform a patriotic concert on July 10, 2008 featuring traditional band music; semi-classics, marches, sacred and folk music arrangements and popular selections.Â Â The Millersville Summer Band concert series has taken place for the past 22 years and includes musicians who are area performers, music department faculty, alumni and friends. The concert will also include a sing-a-long to a handful of familiar tunes, such as "There's No Business Like Show Businessâ and "White Christmas.â
The concert is jointly sponsored by the MU Summer Entertainment Committee and the American Federation of Musicians Performance Fund.
This event is free and open to the public.
Musical selections will include:Â National Anthem; Black Granite March - this is a Patriotic March dedicated to the fallen heroes of the Vietnam conflict; Second Suite for Military Band (Gustav Holst); "The Best of All Possible Worldsâ from Candide (Leonard Bernstein); Â Blue Shades (Frank Tichelli) - this is a favorite arrangement with a blues theme that will feature alumni clarinetist Howard Boots; Crown Imperial March (William Walton); An American In Paris (George Gershwin); Irving Berlin - A Symphonic Portrait; Stars and Stripes Forever (J.P. Sousa).

fulldesc.p: Summer 3

event.title: Hazel I. Jackson and Kenderdine Lectures
event.shortdesc: Ishmael Beah, author of A Long Way Gone

fulldesc.p: Author Ishmael Beah presents:
A LONG WAY GONE: A STORY OF REDEMPTION AND HOPE

Ishmael Beah's book "A Long Way Gone" is being read by Millersville University's incoming freshman class. It was nominated for a Quill Award in the Best Debut Author category for 2007. Time magazine's Lev Grossman named it one of the Top 10 Nonfiction Books of 2007, ranking it at #3, and praising it as "painfully sharp", and its ability to take "takes readers behind the dead eyes of the child-soldier in a way no other writer has."

In 1991, civil war overtook Sierra Leone and Beah'sÂ parents and two brothers were killed. He claims that at the age of 13, he was pressed into service as a child soldier. According to Beah's account, he fought for almost three years before being rescued by UNICEF. He fought in the war, and after the war he continued to fight. Later in 1998, he fled from Freetown due to the increasing violence there and traveled to New York City.
Free and open to the public.Â

Sponsors: Millersville University Commission on Cultural Diversity, Lancaster League of Women's Voter, Black Culture Celebration, CulturalÂ Affairs, School of Humanities and Social Sciences, Common Reading Program, University Theme.

event.title: Film: Praying for Lior
event.fulldesc:
FALL FILM SERIES: Human Rights and Moral Wrongs
"Praying with Lior""An engrossing, wrenching and tender documentary film, 'Praying with Lior' introduces Lior Liebling, also called 'the little rebbe.' Lior has Down syndrome, and has spent his entire life praying with utter abandon. Is he a 'spiritual genius' as many around him say? Or simply the vessel that contains everyone's unfulfilled wishes and expectations? - 'Praying with Lior' is not just a documentary film for diverse audiences. It's also the centerpiece of an ambitious outreach campaign to change the way people with disabilities are perceived and received by faith communities.â (Source: http://www.prayingwithlior.com/ )
Free and Open to the Public

event.title: Home Rule Discussion
event.shortdesc: What is home rule and what will it mean to Lancaster? A Public Forum with Dr. Victor DeSantis, a political scientist and Dean of the Graduate School at Millersville University and the Lancaster County Government Study Commission will be held at Millersville University.
event.fulldesc: Home Rule: A Constitution for Lancaster County What is home rule and what will it mean to Lancaster? A Public Forum with Dr. Victor DeSantis, a political scientist and Dean of the Graduate School at Millersville University and the Lancaster County Government Study Commission will be held at Millersville University September 16, 2008 at 7:pm in the Multi-Purpose Room of the Student Memorial Center. There will be a discussion on the history of local self-governance, a presentation by the Commission and a question and answer period.
event.location: Multi-purpose Room of the Student Memorial Center

event.title: Latinos in Lancaster County: Voices, Perspectives, Myths and Realities
event.shortdesc: Lillian Escobar will discuss her recent research on Latinos in the workforce.
event.fulldesc: Ms. Lillian Escobar-Haskins, former executive director of the Governor of Pennsylvania's Advisory Commission on Latino Affairs, and currently the Policy Director for the Pennsylvania Department of Health, will discuss her recent research on Latinos in the Workforce. She is the co-founder of Alegre Research and Demographics, an organization specializing in community based research.

event.title: Film: Chicago 10
event.fulldesc:
HUMANITIES FILM SERIES
"Chicago 10""Written and directed by Brett Morgen (THE KID STAYS IN THE PICTURE), CHICAGO 10 presents contemporary history with a forced perspective, mixing bold and original animation with extraordinary archival footage that explores the build-up to and unraveling of the Chicago Conspiracy Trial.Â Set to the music of revolution, then and now, CHICAGO 10 is a parable of hope, courage and ultimate victory, the story of young Americans speaking out and taking a stand in the face of an oppressive and armed government." (Sourcehttp://www.participantmedia.com/films/In+Theaters/457/Chicago10)
Free and Open to the Public.Sponsors: The MU CinÃ© Club and The Constitution Day Committee

event.title: 'Ville Idol Deadline for Entries
event.shortdesc:
Deadline for entries for individuals to compete in MU's second 'Ville Idol contest close today, Sept. 19. For details, including application and entry rules, please consult the Ville Idol website: http://www.millersville.edu/~alumni/idol/index.php or by calling the MU Alumni Services Office: 717.872.3352
Competition is open to all MU Undergrads and MU alumni.
Auditions to be held on September 27. Performances to be held: October 11, October 25 and November 9.
For additional questions, please call the MU Alumni Services Office.

fulldesc.p: Deadline for entries for individuals to compete in the second annual 'Ville Idol close on 9/19 @ 4:30 p.m. For contest information, eligibility, rules, etc., please consult the 'Ville Idol website: http://www.millersville.edu/alumni/idol/index.php or by call the MU Alumni Services Office @ 717.872.3352.
Competition is open to ALL MU students and MU alumni. Last year, 58 contestants registered and freshman Theresa Walker and alumnus Matt Hepler received the coveted titles and $1000 each.

Auditions will be held on September 27, while three live performances have been scheduled for October 11, October 25 and November 9 (all @ 3:00 p.m., Lyte Auditorium/Alumni Hall). Tickets go on sale in late September via the Ticket Office, Student Memorial Center.

event.title: Open House
event.shortdesc: Millersville University is hosting a campus Open House on Saturday September 20, 2008. Admissions information, student life, programs of study and financial aid will be among the topics covered.
event.fulldesc: Millersville University is hosting a campus Open House on Saturday September 20, 2008. Admissions information, student life, programs of study and financial aid will be among the topics covered. Campus tours and faculty conferences will also be included in the program. Lunch will be available on campus and may be purchased for a nominal fee. The program will begin at 8:30 a.m. on the Millersville campus. Tour Guides will direct visitors to the starting location. For more information and to register, visit the MU web site at www.millersville.edu or contact the Admissions Office at 1-877-XPLOR MU or (717) 872-3371.

event.title: Quebecois
event.shortdesc: Quebecois - a musical group from Quebec

fulldesc.p: A musical group from Quebec will be at Millersville University for a one-time dance and music performance.

Reveillons! brings to Millersville University the exciting traditional fiddle, dance and vocal music of Quebec. "Reveillons!" is, in French, the present imperative form of the verb "to awaken". Wake up! It is a clear and precise embodiment of the message the band seeks to convey. Indeed, since it was founded in 1996, Reveillons! has been on a mission to reawaken the traditions and culture that lie dormant within each of us. The Quebecois quartet will offer reels, jigs, French songs, step dancing and dances from Quebec to keep you moving throughout the evening.

event.title: Sistahs and Sisters: Black Women White Women
event.shortdesc: Sistahs and Sisters: Black Women: White Women - Acknowledging Differences, Seeking Common Ground by M. Cookie Newsom, Ph.D.

fulldesc.p: Â Sistahs and Sisters: Black Women White Women: Acknowledging Differences, Seeking Common Ground by M. Cookie Newsom, Ph.D.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â
Sponsor(s): Office of Social Equity and Diversity, African American Studies Program, Frederick Douglass Black Culture Celebration, School of Education. Department of Wellness and Sport Science
Â
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

Dr. M. Cookie Newsom holds a BS in Education, a MA in History and a Ph D in Educational Leadership. Her dissertation addressed the achievement gap and was titled "Lessons in Black and White: White teacher questioning practices of black and white students.â She taught high school for 18 years, leaving for a job in higher education. She served as the Director of Student Retention at Clark State College before transitioning to faculty where she was eventually elected chair. She was a research fellow at the Library of Congress for 2002-2003 in the "Cities and Public Spaces in Cultural Contextâ seminar. She is a certified diversity trainer and consultant, NCBI certified and a graduate of the National Institute for Leadership Development. Dr. Newsom has made presentations at many national conferences including American Education Research Association, Mid-west Education Research Association, Patterson Research Conference, North Carolina Association of Financial Aid Administrators and American Council on Education. She currently serves as the Director of Diversity Education and Assessment at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

Dr. Newsom had been married for 40 years, (Wayne) and has four children (Mike, Chris and Nikki), four grandchildren (Marrisa, Julian, Ella and Sam) and two cats ( Agatha Christie and Bucky). She is a member of Phi Theta Kappa, UNC's Faculty and Professional Women Association, UNC's Leadership Institute Board, School of Nursing Multicultural Advisory Board, Orange County Rape Crisis Center Board and is the Chair of the Black Faculty/Staff Caucus at UNC.

event.title: Boys Like Girls
event.shortdesc: Millersville University presents its fall concert, featuring Boys Like Girls, Cute is What We Aim For and Lights on Friday, October 10, 2008. The show is sponsored by the University Activities Board (UAB).

fulldesc.p: Millersville University presents its fall concert, featuring Boys Like Girls, Cute is What We Aim For and Lights on Friday, October 10, 2008. The show is sponsored by the University Activities Board (UAB).

Boys Like Girls, a pop-rock group from Boston, Mass., formed in 2005 and has toured with bands such as Good Charlotte, Butch Walker and Metro Station. Their single, "The Great Escape" hit the U.S. Pop 100 charts at number 9 in 2007. Doors open at 7:00 p.m. at Pucillo Gymnasium at Millersville University and the concert starts at 8:00 p.m.

Tickets are $15 for an MU student (1 per ID), $20 for the general public, and $25 the day of the show. Tickets can be purchased at the Student Memorial Center at Millersville University, by calling 717-872-3811 or online at www.muticketsonline.com. For more information, contact Kaila Repman, UAB concert chair, at 717-586-0724.

event.title: Christie Lecture: John Hatch
event.fulldesc: John Hatch is the founder of FINCA, one of the world's leading microcredit institutions with programs in 23 countries and over one million low-income families assisted since its inception in 1984. Hatch is also known as the father of "village banking", a group loan methodology now replicated by over 800 micro-credit programs in 60 countries.Â Hatch's economic development career spans 44 years, during which time he was a Peace Corps volunteer and staff member (1962-64), Fulbright scholar (PhD. Univ. Wisconsin, 1973), economist, and a consultant to small farmer development projects in some 50 countries (1973-83). In addition to his management duties at FINCA, from 1996 to 2006 John directed field research by summer interns armed with Palm Pilots who interview some 4,000 clients per year to document their poverty levels, business profitability, and rising living standards. Hatch also continues to serve as co-founder and executive committee member of the Microcredit Summit global campaign to reach 175 million of the world's poorest mothers with self-employment loans by the year 2015.Â Although he is now retired, Hatch actively campaigns for an end to global poverty by the year 2025.

event.title: Soulful Expressions
event.shortdesc: Soulful Expressions is an open mike session with poet Shihan.

fulldesc.p: Soulful Expressions
Â
Sponsor: NAACP and Frederick Douglass Black Culture Celebration
Date: October 16, 2008
Time: 7:00
Place: Student Memorial Center Multipurpose Room
No Ticket Required
Contact: Naydia Bonner, (717) 512-7177

Soulful Expressions is an open mike session with spoken word, poetry, and musical selections provided by students and local artists, as well as poet Shihan, seen on Def Poetry Jam.Â Shihan, a native of the lower east side of New York began his career 1989 winning a scholarship for creative writing to the Willston North Hampton School. Â Shihan is one of the most creative and powerful spoken word artist of our time, with awards and accolades to prove so.Â This National Poetry Slam Champion, has made appearances on a slue of media outlets such as Def Poetry, Oprah Winfrey's Oxygen Network, Nike's Battlegrounds, as well as the film Belly.Â Shihan has also participated in the Def Poetry Jam International tour.Â In addition to his many accomplishments, Shihan has two of his own CD's The Poet, and Music Is The New Cotton.
Â

event.title: Worlds End: American Repertory Ballet World Premiere
event.shortdesc: This world premiere will feature American Repertory Ballet's impressive and powerful dancers, the 100-voice strong Millersville University Choral Union and the Continental Trombone Quartet.
event.fulldesc:
Performance: American Repertory Ballet World PremiereÂ
Worlds end. And worlds begin.
Friday, October 17, 2008Â atÂ 7:30 PM
Lyte Auditorium/Alumni Hall
TICKETS
$20.00 Reserved Seating
$15.00 MU ID, Senior Citizens, and Students
$5.00 MU ID two per ID
Tickets can be purchased Mon-Fri, 8:00AM to 4:00PM at the Student Memorial Center or by callingÂ 717-872-3811 and online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com
The American Repertory Ballet(ARB) and renowned choreographer, Graham Lustig, present the world premiere of Worlds end. And worlds begin.This is a new collaborative work based on a text by Richard E. Miller, author of Writing at the End of the World,and music by localÂ composer and Millersville University faculty member, Rusty Banks. Â Don't miss this unique opportunityÂ to witness the birth of a new work. Â The world premiere will feature ARB's impressiveÂ and powerful dancers, the 100-voice strong Millersville University Choral Union and the C Continental Trombone Quartet.
Â
The American Repertory Ballet (ARB), with its mission to convey the joy of dance and present the best in contemporary ballet, is one of America's leading dance companies.Â ARB and its official education arm, the Princeton Ballet School, have a history of dance excellence spanning half acentury. Â Artistic leader, Graham Lustig, considered one of the finest choreographers working today, has created ballets for companies around the globe.Â Â The company hails from places as diverse as Australia, Jamaica, South Africa, Argentine and Brazil, as well as through out the United States.
Â
The collaboration between ARB and Millersville University in the creation of a new work is the first of its kind at Millersville, bringing together the formidable talents of Â Graham Lustig (ARB); Dr. Richard E. Miller, a provocative analyst of the role of the humanities in the 21st century and Chair ofthe Rutgers University English Department; Rusty Banks, an Alabama-born composer and guitarist, now teaching at Millersville University; Dr. Jeffrey Gemmell, a specialistin performing new music by contemporary composers and director of Choral Programs at Millersville University; and the Continental Trombone Quartet, dedicated to the performance of original works composed for the modern trombone quartet.
Â Â

event.title: MU Chapter of Amnesty International hosts Eyes Wide Open: The Human Cost of War
event.shortdesc: The Eyes Wide Open exhibit is a memorial honoring the Pennsylvania soldiers that have lost their lives in the war in Iraq. A pair of combat boots representing each soldier will be laid out with a tag (with the soldier's name) attached to the boots.

fulldesc.p: The Eyes Wide Open: The Human Cost of War exhibit is put on by the American Friends Service Committee (AFSC). The exhibit began as a traveling exhibit honoring all soldiers that have died in Iraq. When the death toll rose to over 4,000 it became too big to travel. The exhibit was divided according to state and the AFSC restarted the exhibit on the state level. Each Pennsylvania soldier that has died in Iraq is represented by a pair of combat boots with their respective names attached. The exhibit is a wonderful memorial to the sacrifice made by soldiers and to the Iraqi civilians who have also lost their lives.

event.location: the Quad (inclement weather location is the Stayer MPR)

event.title: 'Ville Idol
event.shortdesc: Round 2 of the second annual official singing competition for Millersville students and alumni.
event.fulldesc: Round 2 (semi-final) of the second annual official singing competition for MU undergrads and MU alumni. Competition judged vocal ability, stage performance and appearance. Judges include: Kelly West, radio personality (WARM 103.3 FM); Deb Lenssen, singer, conductor and voice instructor at Millersville University; Ray Antonelli, director/producer/actor, Millersville University alumnus, class of 1983 and Ric Zimmerman, singer/performer, American Music Theatre, Sight & Sound Theatre, Continental Singers. Host: Lori Burkholder, news anchor/reporter, WGAL-TV (NBC) and Millersville University alumnus, class of 1989. Final to be held on November 9. For more information on the contest: www.millersville.edu/~alumni/idol/index.php

event.title: 'Ville Idol: Round 2
event.shortdesc: Round 2: Semi-final of 'Ville Idol singing competition

fulldesc.p: top finalist will be named at the end of the program and features two top prizes, in each category (alumni and student): $1,000 and $250. Special entertainment will also be included in this afternoon's program. Host. Lori Burkholder '89. Special guest judges will also be on hand. Final scoring to come from the judges and the audience.

Ticket required: $5 per person (children under 6 free). This contest is sponsored by the MU Alumni Association. Tickets: Student Memorial Center, Ticket Window, MU, 1 S. George Street, Millersville, weekdays, 8:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. or by calling 717-872-3811.

event.title: ATWS 26th Annual Meeting
event.shortdesc: The Association of Third World Studies (ATWS) is holding its organization's 26th annual meeting at Millersville University on October 26-28.

fulldesc.p:
The Association of Third World Studies (ATWS) is holding its organization's 26th annual meeting at Millersville University on October 26-28. The theme of the conference is "Voices of the Subaltern: Identities, Hierarchies and Social Struggles in a Globalizing Age."
Dr. Doyin Coker-Kolo is the conference site coordinator, as well as the associate dean for Millersville’s School of Education. For more information on the conference please contact Coker- Kolo at (717) 871-3816 or by e-mail at dcokerkolo@millersville.edu.

event.title: Race 4 Rita
event.shortdesc:
Race for Rita Committed to Caring 4 Cancer
Sunday, October 26, 2008 Walk starts at 1pm From the Student Memorial Center

fulldesc.p: Race for Rita is a 5k walk around Millersville University to fight against Breast Cancer.Â The event is named in honor of Dr. Rita Smith-Wade-El, Millersville University, Professor of Psychology and community activist, who was recently diagnosed with Triple Negative Breast Cancer.Dr. Rita is currently undergoing chemotherapy and is experiencing intense medical intervention.Â Please come out and learn how you can support women with breast cancer and make a difference in Dr. Rita's life.The walk takes place during Breast Cancer Awareness Month to acknowledge women and families in the surrounding community who know someone affected with breast cancer. Proceeds will help reduce medical expenses for Dr. Rita as well as making a donation to the Triple Negative Breast Cancer Foundation.
Â

event.title: Science and Mathematics Student Research Poster Display

fulldesc.p: Current undergraduate and graduate science and mathematics research projects will be displayed as poster papers. The posters will be displayed in Caputo Hall at Millersville University. This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Slavery & Abolition Collection Digital Launch
event.shortdesc: Join us at the Millersville University Library to celebrate the launch of a collaborative project featuring over 15,000 pages of resources related to slavery & abolition in the United States.

fulldesc.p: "Slavery & Abolition in the U.S.: Select Publications of the 1800s" is a digital collection of books and pamphlets that demonstrate the varying ideas and beliefs about slavery in the United States as expressed by Americans throughout the nineteenth century. The collaborative digitization project was supported in part by the Institute of Museum and Library Services under the provisions of the Library Services and Technology Act as administered by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, in association with Millersville University and Dickinson College.

Please join us on Thursday for the "digital launch" of this collection, featuring refreshments, opportunities to speak with project organizers as well as a look at some of the items included in the collection: both digitally and physically!

p.em: For more information, please contact Marilyn Parrish @ 717-872-3633

event.location: Millersville University Archives and Special Collections - Ganser Library - 4th Floor

event.title: A Cultural Showcase
event.shortdesc: The talents of faculty, students, alumni and staff will be displayed.

fulldesc.p: This special University/community cultural event is highlighted by foods, musical and dance performances and fashion from around the world. Stop by and see the special talents of our faculty, students, alumni and staff. Clubs and organizations will also be on hand to host tables highlighting counties. Sponsored by the University Police, Student Programs, Academic Year Theme, University Activities Board, Finance & Administration, Mary Ann Gerber '67, Sociual Equity and Diversity, Student Affair and the Millersville University Alumni Association. Admission, food and drinks are free.

fulldesc.p: Linda C. Pugh, PhD, RNC, FAAN, "Evidence -Nurses Improve the Quality of Patient Care." Sponsored by the Department ofÂ Nursing and the Xi Chi Chapter of Sigma Theta Tau International, Inc. Join us for a light reception at 6 p.m. followed by the lecture and book signing at 7 p.m. Linda Pugh will be selling copies of her book Johna Hopkins Nursing Evidence-Based Practice Model and Guidelines.
Please contact the Alumni Services Office to make a reservation. Free, but reservations are requested for the reception.

event.location: Lehr Room, Gordinier Hall, Bolger Conference Center

event.title: Film and Speaker: Returned: Child Soldiers of Nepal's Maoist Army
event.shortdesc: Film - Returned: Child Soldiers of Nepal's Maoist Army

fulldesc.h3:
HUMANITIES FILM SERIES - Children at War: A Cinematic Review
Returned:Â Child Soldiers of Nepal's Maoist ArmyandÂ Robert Koenig will speak
fulldesc.p: Nepal recently has begun the peace process to rebuild the country after an eleven-year violent struggle, dubbed the 'People's War' between government security forces and Maoist rebels. Throughout the conflict, both the Nepal Army and the Maoist Army heavily recruited children into their ranks. 'Returned' is a feature length documentary video that follows several Nepali youths as they attempt to reintegrate back into civil society after their association with armed groups linked to the People's War. (Source: http://www.nepaldocumentary.com/TheFilm.aspx)

Director, Editor, and Co-Writer Robert Koenig will speak. Koenig is an Emmy Award-nominated producer, writer, editor, and director [who -] excels in the field of documentary filmmaking. He has completed several documentaries [focusing -] on human rights in Mongolia and Nepal. His work has been seen on PBS, ABC, CBS, and NBC stations throughout the country. Â (Source Ventureproductionspictures.com).
This film complements this year's common reading, A Long Way Gone, Memoirs of a Boy Soldier by Ishmael Beah.
Free and Open to the Public.Â
Sponsors: Frederick Douglass Black Culture Celebration, University Theme, Humanities Film Festival and Common Reading.

fulldesc.p: Open to alumni, faculty, staff and friends. There will be a shotgun start at 10:00 a.m. and the format of play will be scramble. Fee includes: continental-style breakfast, greens fee, 1/2 cart, beverage and snack at the turn, buffet dinner and prizes for closest to the pin, longest drive and straightest drive. NOTE: buffet dinner will be held in Stayer Hall (Multipurpose rooms 100 and 101) on the campus of Millersville University.

Directions to Crossgates Golf Club can be found at their website at www.crossgatesgolf.com. Sponsors: Student Services Inc., Student Lodging Inc., and Millersville University Alumni Association. $90 Advance reservations required.

event.title: Class of 1958 Meet and Mingle

fulldesc.p: The Class of 1958 is invited to meet and mingle at the Campus Grill in Gordinier Hall at the Bolger Conference Center on October 31, 2008.

event.location: Campus Grill, Gordinier Hall, Bolger Conference Center

event.title: 14th Annual Athletic Hall of Fame Reception and Dinner
event.shortdesc: 14th Annual Athletic Hall of Fame Reception and Dinner

fulldesc.p: On October 31, 2008, the 14th Annual Athletic Hall of Fame Reception and Dinner will take place in the Lehr Room in Gordinier Hall at the Bolger Conference Center.

The 2008 honorees include: Ryan Brink, baseball (2001); Gial Cleveland, tennia (1969); Lance Gelnett, basketball (1992); William King, cross country (1985); Sandra Peters, faculty; Diane Espenshade Suhr, field Hocket and softball (1986). For detailed biographies on honorees, please visit the athletics website at www.millersville.edu/~athletic. All alumni and friends are cordially invited to attend. $28 reservations are required.

event.location: Lehr Room in Gordinier Hall at the Bolger Conference Center.
